content.title: Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome
content.definition: Compression of the subclavian artery at the thoracic outlet, causing arterial injury (stenosis, aneurysm, thrombosis) with risk of upper extremity ischemia from embolization or occlusion.

concepts.definition: Where and how arterial compression occurs.

clinical_features.location: Subclavian artery between scalene muscles and first rib
clinical_features.cervical_rib: Present in majority of arterial TOS cases
clinical_features.anomalous_rib: Anomalous first rib or complete cervical rib
clinical_features.mechanism: Repetitive compression causes arterial wall injury

concepts.definition: What happens to the compressed artery.

clinical_features.thrombosis: Thrombus formation in aneurysm or stenosis
clinical_features.embolization: Distal embolization to hand and fingers

clinical_features.pulselessness: Absent radial/ulnar pulses with arm elevation
clinical_features.acute: Acute arm ischemia from embolus or thrombosis

clinical_features.decompression: First rib and cervical rib resection mandatory
clinical_features.arterial_repair: Resection of aneurysm with interposition graft
clinical_features.embolectomy: For acute digital or brachial embolization

clinical_features.rarity: Least common form of TOS (<3% of TOS cases)
clinical_features.urgency: Requires more urgent intervention than other TOS types

content.statement: Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Rare-Syndromes that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome.

citations.source: UpToDate. (2024). Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
